Upchurch"},"height":{"value":"563"},"width":{"value":"1000"},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Align Right"},"value":{"value":"Align Right"}}}}]},"exhibitcarousel":{"results":[]},"pullquote":{"results":[]},"disruptorsignup":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"full-width"},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"fullwidth"},"value":{"value":"Full Width"}}},"callToAction":{"url":"/user-registration/register-mvc","text":"Subscribe"},"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Stay current on your favorite topics"}}},{"mediaID":{"value":"left"},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"left"},"value":{"value":"Left"}}},"callToAction":{"url":"/user-registration/register-mvc","text":"Subscribe"},"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Stay current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKuok Hui Kwong is chair\u003c/strong\u003e of Shangri-La, which has more than 100 hotels in 78 destinations. McKinsey spoke with her about what Chinese luxury travelers want, the strength of the Chinese domestic tourism market, the value of catering to intergenerational travelers, and the importance of giving talent good opportunities. The following is an edited version of the conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e Shangri-La is a global group, but it\u0026rsquo;s very rooted in Asian hospitality, and it attracts many Chinese consumers. Are you seeing different behaviors for luxury travelers from China? Are they beginning to travel more domestically?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKuok Hui Kwong:\u003c/strong\u003e During the COVID-19 pandemic, a lot of wealthy Chinese customers who would have chosen to travel abroad instead spent three years traveling domestically. Now the borders have opened up and international travel is much easier, but I think the habit of consuming travel experiences domestically is a trend that\u0026rsquo;s here to stay. China has truly diverse tourism options, whether you want scenery or culture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough we serve a global luxury audience, we\u0026rsquo;re particularly strong in Asia and have a deep understanding of Chinese consumers. Chinese consumers are increasingly discerning, sophisticated, and confident. While they do buy into bigger brands, I think they\u0026rsquo;re more and more looking for products and experiences that meet their particular needs and that celebrate and reflect their cultural identity. You can see this in the choices they make as they increasingly seek domestic brands, domestic makers, and domestic stay options.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA lot of Chinese luxury travelers are looking for immersive experiences that connect with Chinese culture. They have strong preferences for Chinese food. They\u0026rsquo;re\u0026nbsp;very concerned about safety and hygiene. They have payment options and ride-hailing options that they prefer. Traveling domestically solves for a lot of these issues. It\u0026rsquo;s also become much easier for travelers to reach destinations in China that were previously less accessible, with new flight networks and affordable and efficient high-speed rail connections. So we expect that domestic-experience consumption will continue to be strong.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause it\u0026rsquo;s such a huge market, fortunes can surge based on the customer\u0026rsquo;s domestic preferences. But it also means that the market is extremely competitive. It changes very fast. And consumers\u0026rsquo; needs are constantly evolving. It also means it\u0026rsquo;s a market that can accept and looks for a lot of innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e What sort of innovation is this discerning group of travelers looking for? What are you doing to innovate at Shangri-La?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKuok Hui Kwong:\u003c/strong\u003e For us at Shangri-La, we\u0026rsquo;re seeing a lot of domestic leisure trips in China that are built around school holidays\u0026mdash;with more and more parents taking their children on holiday to experience different parts of the country. So one of the main areas we\u0026rsquo;re very focused on is the family experience. In the China context, when we talk about experience seeking, a lot of times it\u0026rsquo;s multigenerational. It\u0026rsquo;s parents with their children, or it\u0026rsquo;s grandparents and parents and children all together.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause Chinese families are becoming smaller, their ability and willingness to spend on family experiences has gotten larger. The perception that Chinese luxury travelers only want to go overseas to buy high-end brands is no longer true. A new generation of luxury consumers wants to share experiences and quality moments with their families.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDialing into the family experience is definitely something we\u0026rsquo;ve been working on, even before the pandemic. A lot of hotels are eyeing this market as well. We own a lot of our underlying assets. So rather than just putting a kid\u0026rsquo;s tent in a room, for example, we can create an end-to-end, integrated, holistic experience that can be delightful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e In Singapore, we launched our first family experience urban hotel in 2016, when we created a several-hundred-square-meter play zone. We repurposed two tennis courts to turn them into an outdoor splash and  play water zone. And then we created a whole floor of family rooms and suites with differently themed rooms that would appeal to children. We continued this in Hong Kong and in Beijing, where we opened during the pandemic, and have plans to grow this in other destinations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother area where we see a lot of innovation is food and beverage. That can mean regional cuisine, menu items, concepts, design and d\u0026eacute;cor of restaurants, and the pairing of food with wine or \u003cem\u003ebaijiu\u003c/em\u003e [a clear liquor], along with the use of local Chinese products and Chinese cuisine with international accents.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e One big issue in the industry is talent retention\u0026mdash;especially talent at the level where you have to train for not just general service but also your own brand standards and unique Asian hospitality touches. What do you do to attract and retain that talent and help them grow in the industry?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKuok Hui Kwong:\u003c/strong\u003e I think that has to be part of your way of doing business and your corporate culture. What I personally love about Shangri-La is that it\u0026rsquo;s in our DNA to really care for our colleagues. We really lived this during the pandemic. In most of our markets, we were the very last to consider reducing our frontline workforce, and even when we did, it was minimal. This wasn\u0026rsquo;t a decision I made on my own\u0026mdash;this is part of our culture, which I am very proud of. It also enabled us to ramp up much quicker postpandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s also about giving opportunities to some of our colleagues to move out of their home markets and develop their careers in a global setting. We\u0026rsquo;re one of the few Asian-headquartered companies that can afford to give a local Asian workforce global opportunities. And I think we can do even more of that going forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eComments and opinions expressed by interviewees are their own and do not represent or reflect the opinions, policies, or positions of McKinsey \u0026amp; Company or have its endorsement.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The chair of Shangri-La on the unique preferences of Chinese luxury travelers"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Scrolling"},"value":{"value":"scrolling"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatthew D. Upchurch is founder,\u003c/strong\u003e chairman, and CEO of the luxury-travel-advising network Virtuoso. McKinsey spoke with Upchurch about his definition of luxury, his sense of what today\u0026rsquo;s luxury consumers are looking for, and his view on the evolution of the luxury-travel advisor. The following is an edited version of the conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e We\u0026rsquo;ll start with a question that seems simple but isn\u0026rsquo;t\u0026mdash;how do you define the luxury-travel segment?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatthew Upchurch:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026ldquo;Luxury\u0026rdquo; is an overused word, and not just in travel. People might try to quantify it and define it according to spending amounts. But to me, it\u0026rsquo;s more nuanced than that.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eStart with the traveler. We now have five generations of people all traveling at the same time. And each luxury traveler may have many distinct personas, which change based on their stage of life and what kind of trip they\u0026rsquo;re taking. Are they traveling in a group, with family, on a \u0026ldquo;bleisure\u0026rdquo; trip? Then there are the hotel properties. As more commoditized segments get better at things like hyperpersonalization, and their hardware and design get better, it sometimes becomes harder to differentiate them from the luxury segment. We need to look at things more holistically.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe real differentiator is how the customer feels. A luxury experience often means finding someone who will truly listen to what you want and then deliver beyond expectations. When it comes to helping a customer plan travel, good travel advisors differentiate by asking, \u0026ldquo;How do you want to feel on this trip? How do you want to feel when it\u0026rsquo;s over?\u0026rdquo; Determining this desired outcome is what helps deliver a truly modern luxury experience tailored specifically to the client.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen this happens over multiple planning cycles, the advisor becomes a specialist in you, the client. Advisors can\u0026rsquo;t possibly know every part of the world\u0026mdash;they have a global network at their disposal for that. But having someone who specializes in you, who knows your likes and dislikes and exactly how you want to travel without you having to explain it every time you plan a trip\u0026mdash;that\u0026rsquo;s luxury.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerhaps, though, the simplest definition of luxury from the customer\u0026rsquo;s point of view is: \u0026ldquo;Of course I could do it myself. I don\u0026rsquo;t want to. And if I can have someone in my life who provides incredible experiences and is a fun collaborator, takes my input, has great connections, and can watch my back and do things for me, why would I want to do it myself?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e What kind of fundamental changes are you seeing in terms of destination picks or product picks among your luxury travelers?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatthew Upchurch:\u003c/strong\u003e With luxury experiential travelers, the fundamental creative tension is between the familiar and the unfamiliar. There\u0026rsquo;s often the desire to go back to places they love and have built relationships with over time\u0026mdash;to show them to family and friends and see them through new eyes. But people want to know before they return to a familiar destination: Is there a new story happening there? I\u0026rsquo;ve been to Madrid many times in my life, so is there a new story in Madrid? Is there a new story in London? Has the destination itself transformed so that it\u0026rsquo;s familiar but still feels new?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe\u0026rsquo;re also seeing a strong desire to explore. That\u0026rsquo;s one of the reasons expedition cruising is doing incredibly well. Expedition cruising is high end, not mass, and it\u0026rsquo;s absolutely bringing new luxury travelers to cruising.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause we\u0026rsquo;re starting to see a recurring issue with overcrowding at some destinations, we\u0026rsquo;re also seeing a lot of our sophisticated travelers increasingly taking trips during what was once called the \u0026ldquo;shoulder season.\u0026rdquo; They don\u0026rsquo;t want to be caught in an overcrowded major city in Europe in the summer, so either they\u0026rsquo;ll visit in September or October, or they\u0026rsquo;ll focus on secondary or tertiary cities instead. We\u0026rsquo;re even seeing some travelers going to Europe in November, December, and January. We call it the \u0026ldquo;cultural season.\u0026rdquo; I used to sell it by saying, \u0026ldquo;Why don\u0026rsquo;t you go there when the citizens are happy instead of annoyed with everybody that\u0026rsquo;s overwhelming their cities?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e You have a rich repository of feedback from your clients. If you had to give one message to luxury-accommodation providers, what would it be?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatthew Upchurch:\u003c/strong\u003e First, they need to get really good at being able to measure what\u0026rsquo;s not easily measurable. Because those are the things that make it luxury.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, focus on staff culture. It\u0026rsquo;s crucial to engage with your employees and understand them. We need to make sure the people delivering the experiences feel fulfilled. I absolutely believe that those hospitality players that really focus on their employees, their culture, their service levels\u0026mdash;those properties where you can truly feel the presence of the general manager\u0026mdash;are the ones that will excel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAverage daily room rates have been rising quickly. And the properties that don\u0026rsquo;t effectively focus on the experiences of both their employees and their customers will have trouble maintaining those high rates. Because lately we hear a lot of our customers saying, \u0026ldquo;I have never paid this much before. I used to pay $900 a night for a hotel in Miami, now it\u0026rsquo;s $2,000 for the same hotel, and frankly, the value isn\u0026rsquo;t there.\u0026rdquo; When price and value don\u0026rsquo;t align, it\u0026rsquo;s a huge danger for the property, and it will come back to haunt them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e What kind of evolution have you seen in the way luxury travelers engage with travel advisors?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatthew Upchurch:\u003c/strong\u003e If you go back to the middle of the 20th century, more people booked directly with the actual providers than they do today. International flights were a high-end product. Walking into Pan Am airline\u0026rsquo;s office on Fifth Avenue in 1950 was like walking into Bergdorf Goodman. There was pleasure in it. There was also very little pricing complexity because there were essentially just four fare classes\u0026mdash;day coach, night coach, day first class, and night first class.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo why would people use a travel advisor if a lot of providers had fabulous service and there was no price complexity? They did it for the same core reasons that they do it today. One is community knowledge: travel advisors have the collective knowledge of the community that they serve. They know what\u0026rsquo;s on the minds of other high-net-worth individuals that the customer respects. Another is the value of relationships: the customer might have heard of a certain luxury property, but the travel advisor might have a personal relationship with the general manager of the property.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThings changed in the 1970s, when airfare classes got more complicated, and many travel agents made money by basically becoming human interfaces to the airline reservation systems. Things changed again in the late 1990s with the arrival of the online travel agencies like Expedia and Travelocity. The idea then was the consumer could do it themselves, and it would be cheaper than paying for the travel agent\u0026rsquo;s labor. That did cause a large exit of agents from the industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the true travel advisors, who were consultative and not transactional, continued to thrive by building on community knowledge and relationships. At Virtuoso, we never believed that all the baby boomers\u0026mdash;who invented the personal chef, personal shopper, personal everything\u0026mdash;would suddenly start doing travel DIY.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e What\u0026rsquo;s happened generally in the profession is that the successful luxury-travel advisor needs more of a right-brain attitude, asking the customer open-ended questions. In a world where there are an endless number of answers, what really impresses a well-educated, sophisticated customer isn\u0026rsquo;t that you have answers; it\u0026rsquo;s that you ask great questions. The minute you ask a question they hadn\u0026rsquo;t thought about, it stops them in their tracks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAny good travel advisor today will add value in three separate areas: before the trip, during the trip, and after the trip. The number-one thing that high-net-worth consumers tell us differentiates a trusted travel advisor from a transactional travel agent is the quality and consistency of post-trip debriefs. That debrief is when it becomes a learning relationship.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf customers can see that those debriefs add value to the next trip, and the one after that, it makes them very \u0026ldquo;sticky.\u0026rdquo; A lot of our sophisticated travelers are planning big milestone trips three, four, or five years in advance. And a lot of our advisors are saying, \u0026ldquo;Let\u0026rsquo;s not work at one trip at a time. Let\u0026rsquo;s have a strategy.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhy would you have a professional collaborator who helps you make a proactive, conscious plan to optimize your financial assets but not have a professional collaborator who helps you plan how to optimize your most valuable, nonrenewable asset\u0026mdash;your free leisure time? If you lose money, you can make it back. If you lose time, you\u0026rsquo;ll never get it back. Motivating the customer to think that way can drive a huge amount of value.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eComments and opinions expressed by interviewees are their own and do not represent or reflect the opinions, policies, or positions of McKinsey \u0026amp; Company or have its endorsement.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The founder of Virtuoso on the evolution of the luxury-travel advisor"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom
